questions.text: What is the causative agent responsible for causing acne fulminans among the following options?
questions.solution:
• An abnormal immune response to the bacterium Propionibacterium acnes is thought to be the cause of the rare and severe form of acne known as acne fulminans. The exact cause of acne fulminans, on the other hand, is still poorly understood. Genetic predisposition, hormonal imbalances, and certain medications like isotretinoin are additional factors that could contribute to the onset of this condition.
  • The genus of bacteria known as Propionibacterium is commonly found on human skin, particularly in areas of the face, scalp, and upper back that produce a lot of oil. These Gram-positive bacteria are anaerobic or facultatively anaerobic and do not produce spores. Propionibacterium acnes is known to be engaged with the improvement of skin breakout, in spite of the fact that it is likewise a typical occupant of the skin microbiome and plays other helpful parts in the body. 

Incorrect choices:

  • Option a. Actinomyces: The bacteria of the genus Actinomyces are typically found in the gastrointestinal tract, throat, and mouth of humans and other animals. Gram-positive, anaerobic or microaerophilic, and filamentous, these bacteria produce long, branching structures that are known as filaments. Actinomyces species are essential members of the human body's normal microbiota and contribute to oral and digestive health.
  • Option c. Mobiluncus: The bacteria in the genus Mobiluncus are anaerobic, Gram-variable, and curved or comma-shaped, like shrimps. These bacteria are frequently found in the female genital tract and are linked to bacterial vaginosis (BV), a condition characterized by an overgrowth of certain bacteria in the vagina that can result in itching, odor, and discharge. Mobiluncus microorganisms are much of the time present in big numbers in females with BV, alongside different microscopic organisms, for example, Gardnerella vaginalis.
  • Option d. Bifidobacterium: Bifidobacterium is a variety of microscopic organisms that are normally tracked down in the human gastrointestinal parcel and different pieces of the body, like the mouth and vagina. These microorganisms are anaerobic, Gram-positive, and non-spore-framing, and they have a trademark Y-or Angular shape. Due to their crucial role in maintaining gut health and immunity, Bifidobacterium species are regarded as beneficial or "friendly" bacteria.

questions.text: Which cell is absent from the layer indicated as D?
questions.solution:
Correct Ans: D 

  • Langerhans cells: Langerhans cells are specialized immune cells present in the epidermis. They play a role in immune surveillance and antigen presentation. Langerhans cells are typically found in the more superficial layers of the epidermis, particularly in the stratum spinosum layer. Therefore, Langerhans cells are not present in the marked stratum basale layer. This option is correct.

Incorrect Option:

Option A. Keratinocyte: Keratinocytes are the predominant cells in the epidermis and are responsible for producing the protein keratin, which contributes to the strength and waterproofing of the skin. Keratinocytes are present in the stratum basale layer, so they are indeed present in the marked layer. This option is incorrect.

Option B. Merkel cell: Merkel cells are specialized sensory cells found in the skin that play a role in touch sensation. They are typically found in the stratum basale layer, forming connections with nerve endings. Therefore, Merkel cells are present in the marked layer. This option is incorrect.

Option C. Melanocyte: Melanocytes are pigment-producing cells responsible for the production of melanin, which gives color to the skin, hair, and eyes. Melanocytes are primarily located in the stratum basale layer and extend their processes into the surrounding layers. Based on the image, it is not possible to determine the presence of melanocytes in the marked layer. This option is inconclusive.

questions.text: Which one of the subsequent options represents a primary skin lesion?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C: Purpura

  • Purpura: Purpura is indeed a primary skin lesion.
  • It refers to the purple or red discoloration of the skin caused by bleeding into the skin or mucous membranes.
  • Purpura occurs due to various factors, including vascular fragility, platelet disorders, or clotting abnormalities. It can appear as small pinpoint spots (petechiae) or larger patches (ecchymosis) on the skin.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Crust: Crust is not a primary skin lesion but rather a secondary change. It forms when dried exudate or blood accumulates on the skin surface, resulting in a scab or crust. Crusts are commonly seen in conditions like impetigo or eczema, but they are a result of an underlying primary lesion.

Option B - Atrophy: Atrophy is not considered a primary skin lesion but a secondary change. It refers to a thinning or wasting of the skin layers, leading to a reduction in skin thickness. Atrophy can occur due to various reasons, such as long-term use of corticosteroids or certain skin diseases. However, it is not an initial or fundamental skin abnormality.

Option D - Induration: Induration is also not a primary skin lesion but a secondary feature. It refers to the palpable or firm thickening of the skin, often associated with underlying inflammation, fibrosis, or cellular infiltration. Induration can be observed in conditions such as cellulitis or scleroderma, but it is not the primary skin lesion itself.

Correct option C

  • The lines shown in the image are called Blaschko lines. Blaschko lines represent the patterns of embryonic cell migration and proliferation during the development of the skin. These lines are not visible under normal circumstances but become apparent in certain conditions, such as genetic mosaicism or certain skin disorders.

Incorrect options:

Option A: Lymphatic development: Lymphatic development refers to the formation and maturation of the lymphatic system, which is responsible for maintaining fluid balance and immune function. It does not directly relate to the horizontal lines seen in the image.

Option B: Dermatomes: Dermatomes are specific areas of the skin that are innervated by sensory nerves from a single spinal nerve root. They represent the sensory distribution of the spinal nerves and are not related to the horizontal lines seen in the image.

Option D: Vascular development: Vascular development refers to the formation and maturation of blood vessels during embryonic development. While blood vessels are present in the skin and may follow certain patterns, they are not directly associated with the specific horizontal lines shown in the image.
